Comments_List: I learned about entropy and its very many applications.

A broad yet sufficiently deep introduction into information theory as a mathematical topic and into some of its notable applications. A useful study into topics at the intersection of mathematics, probability, and computer science.
Basic concepts of information theory and some actual applications in finance and communication.

1. Wide range of information theory related topics
2. Their potential applications in communication, finance and machine learning. 
3. The way to look into this world from information point of view.
Problem sets were very helpful in learning the material, but also very long. Could be shorter and get the same level of understanding.
I felt that the course focused too much on Statistics, disproportionately to the applications Information Theory has in other domains.

Strengths are the excellent lecture quality, well-balance between depth of presentation and breadth of material covered, and content/assignment difficulty that is challenging and instructive without seeming cruel. A first weakness is that although the assignments were thoughtful in difficulty, they were overly time consuming --- quite frequently a few problems in each set felt repetitive and unnecessary after the content had been learned from other problems of similar design. Second, information theory has a diverse set of applications to which the second half of the course was primarily oriented, and the class might benefit from more student feedback as to interest in those applications. For example, substantial amount of time was spent on gambling and finance despite nearly no students noting a focus on those topics, whereas other topics like error correcting codes and algorithmic information theory were not covered.
The course is well organized. It covers most of the important basic topics about information theory and offers sufficient exercise, making it a very good math course.
Everything in great detail. Homework well given
Useful materials were covered, but not very organized.
Yes, the material was interesting and Prof. Barron is very good at motivating intuition of the material.

I'd absolutely recommend the first half of the course. The second half would depend on the relative interest of the other student on the information theoretic application topics --- finance and statistics --- that seem to be favored.
